text: uh hi everyone pushing through the pain
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
armond hammer and
the alchemist project haram this is a
brand new
lp from one of abstract hip-hop's most
exciting duos in the underground at the
moment that's arm and hammer
teaming up with legendary producer the
alchemist for an entire project of beats
who is armond hammer they are new york
rappers billy woods
and lucid who had an incredible run
together through the 2010s dropping some
of my favorite hip hop records of that
decade
race music as well as the impeccably
produced paraffin
not only that but over this course of
time i also have loved
seeing the duo grow in terms of profile
becoming a truly beloved duo with a
strong cult following
and i think it certainly says something
that someone of the
alchemist's background and popularity is
interested
in working with them i mean the man's
massive production discography
spans decades and speaks for itself and
he's still dropping critically acclaimed
material today like his
recent releases with freddie gibbs baldi
james even haram here seems to be
getting a very positive reception
now i will admit despite listening to
arm and hammer and billy woods music for
years this project did throw me for a
loop a little bit
in a good way because up until this
point arm and hammer's been nothing if
not consistent in terms of their
sonic and lyrical vibe but they really
seem to be leaning into their
impressionistic tendencies
on this one and the alchemist seems
happy to go there with them case and
point the track pepper tree
where billy woods accents his surreal
free associative spoken word bars
over reversed jazz loops it's trippy
it's bizarre
it's out there even for arm and hammer
there's a decent handful of sun
tracks on this record too that i didn't
really see coming either
god's feet where both billy and ellucid
deliver
forlorn vocal leads over some chilling
electric piano passages
there's also the closer stone fruit
where a lucid
uh performs in this deep
bellowing rasp meanwhile the
instrumental reads like a woozy piece of
vintage psych rock
the graveled roar of a lucid's voice on
this track almost reminds me of
the vocals of that dancehall artist
assassin but in comparison
lucid's execution is noticeably stiffer
uh
look i'm not crazy about the singing on
this lp
and i guess you could make the argument
that billy and lucid aren't exactly out
to
prove themselves as proficient singers i
sort of see it as playing into an
overall purposeful
rawness of this project that you either
get something out of or you don't
so even if the singing did read to me as
being too awkward maybe with the
exception of squeegee
ultimately i do think it complements
this record's winding
tapestry of moody beats grim vs
subtly psychedelic effects and motif
based song
structures many of the tracks on this
record flow into each other seamlessly
as well
using some strange sound effects or
vocal clips or
bits of instrumental to kind of coast
from one moment to the next
you could say this lp delivers a more
holistic listen as opposed to
a set of tracks that are all very
clearly defined which
again i think is appropriate given the
instrumentals and the tone of the lyrics
here
it feels like i'm just moving through
the snapshots of a fever dream
check the opening track for example
never has armand hammer's vibe felt so
potent but
also elusive with the slow drum and kick
pattern
surrounded with all of these swelling
reversed
tones and melodies the whole thing just
creeps in like a sense of dread
with billy wood's opening verse he spits
bars on bars that read like old adages
following this a lucid flows with the
precision of a samurai as usual
the rhyme schemes are mwah especially
when he hits on a certain word or or
rhyme and he'll just combo it again and
again and again and again
and of course his words can be pregnant
with meaning too
take the shorter cut roaches don't fly
for example which follows immediately
after where i get a lot of themes of
separation and partitioning off
socially and culturally maybe as a means
of preservation
fortification falling away from spaces
that don't serve a sacred purge
extracted herbs smack my new name
colonizers can't pronounce and of course
the whole thing ends with this mantra
that
you don't have to be here if you don't
want a lucid sounding like a
ghost that's haunting away anyone who
just
might not be on the wavelength of this
record the instrumental on black
sunlight also has a very
strange almost twilight zone sort of
quality to it between the skipping vocal
keyboard and drum loops i feel like i'm
listening to
just a broken soul record on lsd and
while everything
instrumentally may come off very woozy
and very strange billy woods is just so
concrete and so in your face and so
clear and such an
authority of a sound brutally spinning
all of these dense bits of wordplay
and juxtapositions like the smoking at
church bar
or even the likening of arm and hammer
to hagler and hearns
shorted them like bear stearns billy
just says so much with every cultural
reference whether that be a legendary
boxing match or
the 2000s meltdown of wall street
billy's portion of the track radiates
this unconcerned energy as he says
which elucid as he follows up on the
back end amplifies even louder
this is maybe the most upbeat set of
bars i've ever heard from
ellucid on any track ever meanwhile as
billy raps at the beginning of indian
summer
it's like he's delivering i don't know
the origin
story of some kind of villain i swore
vengeance in the seventh grade not on
one man but the whole human race
i'm almost done god be praised i'm
almost done
every debt gets paid i used to cut grass
and smile like i meant it we squatted in
the shade when the mowers overheated
and you know what knowing billy woods uh
lyrical pedigree and
uh the things he's rapped about in the
past i have a feeling he's not talking
about landscaping
there is a little lull around the
midpoint that lasts a few tracks in my
opinion
but things do pick up pretty quickly
with the blissfully psychedelic falling
out the sky
which begins with an earl sweatshirt
feature billy and a lucid follow up
through the rest of the track with a lot
of bars in their verses that are quite
poetic
and reference idyllic memories
collectively there is a fantastically
grim
energy with billy and a lucid and amani
as well as curly castro on wishing bad
and quelly chris's feature on
chicharones is absolutely a perfect
fit for this record too there is
something about his flow
and his nasally delivery that typically
comes off
very loose and this is a very loose
record a very falling out of touch with
the material world kind of lp
if there's any selling point to this
record it's that
and the ways in which the alchemist's
production enhances that
i will also say for someone who's been
listening to arm and hammer for a while
billy and ellucid thematically
with their verses across this project
were
like really on the same page more than
ever not that they've ever uh
been working as like completely separate
entities but
it seems like there was more of a
focused effort than
before to like really make sure that
they're hitting upon the same themes and
vibes
on a lot of these cuts which could have
been a priority considering how
great some of the switch-ups between
these tracks can be
emotionally and subject-wise too so
while i can't say this is my favorite
arm and hammer project
i did love it i did come away from this
project enjoying it quite a bit
there were tracks around the midpoint i
wasn't crazy about it does not have the
strongest ending
of an arm and hammer project either in
my opinion even if billywood's final
verse on the entire record
is like soul crushing i also have to
note i feel this album
qualifies as one of my favorite kinds of
collaborations when i do hear two
artists
crossing over in such a big way and that
is you have these two separate entities
coming together to
create something that they could not
have done separately this is not a sound
this is not a vibe i believe that arm
and hammer would have
gone for or achieved without the
alchemist
teaming up with them and vice versa i
don't think this is the
kind of record you would typically
expect the alchemist uh
to have his hand in if not for the fact
that armenhamer was there kind of
providing that opportunity and obviously
their artistic
talents uh make the prospect of doing
that attempting one for any producer
that actually
kind of cares about his craft and cares
about hip-hop as a whole not just the
mainstream stuff but what's bubbling up
in the underground too
feeling a strong seven to a light eight
on this lp
